title: Korean Phonology and Foreign Word Transcription

elements.content: Have you ever wondered how Korean speakers perceive and transcribe foreign words? A fascinating example can be found in the way biblical names were rendered in early Korean translations of the Bible. Unlike modern standardized transliterations, these phonetic adaptations were based on how Korean speakers at the time actually heard and reproduced foreign sounds. This phenomenon reveals key aspects of Korean phonology and its interaction with loanword adaptation.

One of the most distinctive features of early biblical translations in Korean is the way proper names and unit words were transcribed. Consider the following examples from an early Korean translation of the Bible:
“Then he said to Thomas, ‘Put your finger here; see my hands. Reach out your hand and put it into my side. Stop doubting and believe.’ Thomas said to him, ‘My Lord and my God!’” (John 20:27-28, NIV)
“Then he said to Thomas, ‘Put your finger here; see my hands. Reach out your hand and put it into my side. Stop doubting and believe.’ Thomas said to him, ‘My Lord and my God!’” (John 20:27-28, NIV)

“Peter knocked at the outer entrance, and a servant named Rhoda came to answer the door. When she recognized Peter’s voice, she was so overjoyed she ran back without opening it and exclaimed, ‘Peter is at the door!’” (Acts 12:13-14, NIV)

“Peter knocked at the outer entrance, and a servant named Rhoda came to answer the door. When she recognized Peter’s voice, she was so overjoyed she ran back without opening it and exclaimed, ‘Peter is at the door!’” (Acts 12:13-14, NIV)
“They made the atonement cover of pure gold—two and a half cubits long and a cubit and a half wide. Then they made two cherubim out of hammered gold at the ends of the cover.” (Exodus 37:6-7, NIV)
“They made the atonement cover of pure gold—two and a half cubits long and a cubit and a half wide. Then they made two cherubim out of hammered gold at the ends of the cover.” (Exodus 37:6-7, NIV)

In these passages, the names Thomas , Peter , and Cubit appear as 도마 (Doma) , 베드로 (Bedro) , and 규빗 (Gyubit) , respectively, in early Korean translations. Compared to modern transliterations— 토마스 (Thomas) , 페트로스 (Petros) , and 큐빗 (Cubit) —there is a clear difference in how these words were adapted. The older versions used ㄷ, ㅂ, and ㄱ (tense consonants in Korean), whereas modern transcriptions employ ㅌ, ㅍ, and ㅋ (aspirated consonants).

This difference arises from a fundamental distinction between Korean and English phonology. In English, the contrast between voiced (e.g., b, d, g) and voiceless (e.g., p, t, k) consonants is phonemically significant, meaning they distinguish words. However, in Korean, this distinction is much less prominent. Instead, Korean speakers primarily differentiate sounds based on aspiration (the strength of the airflow following the consonant), rather than voicing.

For example, an English-speaking missionary might have pronounced Thomas (/ˈtɒməs/) with an unaspirated /t/ at the beginning, which a Korean listener would perceive as closer to 도 (do) rather than 토 (to) . Similarly, Peter (/ˈpiːtər/) and Cubit (/ˈkjuːbɪt/) were transcribed as 베드로 (Bedro) and 규빗 (Gyubit) , using less aspirated consonants that sounded more natural to native Korean speakers.

Another noticeable pattern in Korean biblical translations is the frequent omission of final consonants in foreign words.
For instance, Thomas (토마스) appears as 도마 (Doma) and Judas (유다스) as 유다 (Yuda) . Similarly, Artemis becomes 아데미 (Ademi) , and Hermes is transcribed as 허메 (Home) .

This simplification can be attributed to Korean syllable structure constraints . In Korean, only a limited set of consonants ( ㄱ, ㄴ, ㄷ, ㄹ, ㅁ, ㅂ, ㅇ ) can appear at the end of a syllable. Sounds like -s or -r , common in English and Greek, are difficult to pronounce in a Korean phonological framework. Instead of approximating them, early translators simply omitted them.

Additionally, another hypothesis is that these translations might not have been based on nominative case forms but rather on vocative forms of Greek names. In Koine Greek, names like Petros (Πέτρος) or Loukas (Λουκᾶς) have vocative forms Petre (Πέτρε) and Louka (Λουκᾶ), which naturally lack the final -s. If early Korean translators used these forms, it would explain the absence of the final consonants.

A particularly intriguing case is the name 누가 (Nuga) , which corresponds to Luke (Λουκᾶς, Lucas). Unlike previous examples, which retained the original word’s consonant structure, Loukas was adapted in a way that aligns with a unique phonological rule in Korean— the Initial Sound Rule (두음 법칙, Dueum Beopchik).

In Korean, word-initial r sounds (ㄹ) are often replaced with n (ㄴ), particularly in Sino-Korean words. For example, the Chinese-derived word for “donkey” (驢) was historically pronounced 라귀 (Ragwi) but later changed to 나귀 (Nagwi) . Similarly, Lukas (루카) may have undergone this transformation, resulting in 누가 (Nuga) instead of the expected 루가 (Luga) .

Interestingly, this rule does not apply to modern foreign words (e.g., radio is 라디오 , not 나디오 ). However, the presence of this pattern in biblical names suggests that the rule was once more rigorously applied, even to foreign loanwords. This showcases how phonological constraints evolve over time and how Korean phonology has changed even within the last two centuries.

At first glance, the early transcription of biblical names into Korean may seem inconsistent or arbitrary. However, upon closer examination, these adaptations reveal systematic phonological patterns, deeply rooted in how Korean speakers perceive and categorize sounds.

These historical transcriptions offer a glimpse into not only the phonological nature of the Korean language but also how language adapts over time to accommodate foreign elements. Looking back at these linguistic transformations is not just an academic exercise—it’s a way to appreciate the dynamism of language and its intricate relationship with culture and history.
